net.sf.mmm.util.datatype.api.phone

Class PhoneNumber

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.util.lang.api.AbstractDatatype
      • net.sf.mmm.util.lang.api.AbstractSimpleDatatypeBase<String>
        • net.sf.mmm.util.datatype.api.phone.PhoneNumber
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, AttributeReadValue<String>, Datatype, SimpleDatatype<String>

    public class PhoneNumber
extends AbstractSimpleDatatypeBase<String>
    This is the interface for a phone number. In this context phone number means an international number that potentially connects to an end-point via the phone network (PTSIN, VoIP, etc.) from anywhere in the world. This means that some numbers accepted by your phone may NOT be valid in the sense of this datatype (e.g. "**6#1"). On the other hand a phone number that is syntactically correct but does not point to an existing line, will still be accepted (e.g. "+49 69 987654321").
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        Returns:
        the AreaCode.

      • getLocalNumber

        public String getLocalNumber()
        This method gets the local number (subscriber number) excluding the extension.
        Returns:
        the subscriber number.

      • getExtension

        public String getExtension()
        This method gets the extension (also called DDI - direct dial in). Phone customers that have multiple phone numbers typically have a common prefix for all their phone numbers and only the last digits differ. In this case these group of digits is called extension. Typically this is separated by a hyphen character ('-') when the phone number is formatted.
        Returns:
        the extension.

      • getValue

        public String getValue()
        This method gets the actual phone number (e.g. "+49 (0)69 987654-321"). This method returns the raw value of this datatype. This will typically be a standard datatype (like String, Character, Boolean, any type of Number, any type of java.time.LocalDate, etc.).
        Returns:
        the value of this datatype.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns the official String representation of this Datatype. While the general contract of Object.toString() is very weak and mainly used for debugging, the contract here is very strong. The returned String has to be suitable for end-users and official output to any kind of sink.
        ATTENTION:
        This method is not supposed to do internationalization (I18N). See NlsMessage for this purpose and implement NlsObject if you want to support I18N/L10N.
        Specified by:
        toString in interface Datatype
        Overrides:
        toString in class AbstractSimpleDatatypeBase<String>
        Returns:
        the official String representation to display the value of this Datatype.
